column5: description
Afrikaans is a Germanic language spoken by about 7 million native speakers mainly in South Africa and Namibia. It is represented here in the standard orthography.
Amharic is a Semitic languages spoken by about 22 million native speakers mainly in Ethiopia.
Ampari is a Western Dogon language, belonging to the Mombo-Ampari subgroup and is spoken in a smaller area south of the Mombo area, including Nando village.

Standard Arabic (Modern Standard Arabic, Literary Arabic, similar: Classical Arabic) is the standardized variety of Arabic used in writing and highly formal speech. It is an official language in 27 states in western Asia and northern Africa. Standard Arabic is represented here in the Hans Wehr transliteration.

Bankan Tey ('Walo Language') is an Eastern Dogon language, belonging to the Beni-Walo-Nanga subgroup and is spoken in a village cluster Walo (old French spelling Oualo, native name Bankan) at the eastern end of the very long Gandamiya inselberg, not far from Douentza. Walo is a well-known site for pottery-making (large globular water jars without feet). In the past, Walo and Beni had a single chief, alternating between the two villages.
Basaa (Basa, Mbene) is a Bantu language (A43) spoken by about 300 000 speakers in central-west Cameroon.
Burunge is a Southern Cushitic language spoken by about 13 000 speakers in Tanzania. It is represented here in the standardized orthography.
Beja (Bedawi, Bidhaawyeet) is a Northern Cushitic language spoken by probably more than 1 million speakers in eastern Sudan.

Ben Tey ('Beni Language') is an Eastern Dogon language, belonging to the Beni-Walo-Nanga subgroup and is spoken in the villages of Beni and to a lesser extent Gamni (3 km apart). Both villages are on a relatively narrowl rocky shelf (plateau) south of Douentza. A divergent dialect is said to be spoken in the village of Komboy.

Bunoge (exonyms include Korandabo) is an Eastern Dogon language, belonging to the Beni-Walo-Nanga subgroup and is spoken in the villages of Boudou and Sangou. It is a small-population language and potentially endangered.
Bilin (Bilen) is a Central Cushitic (or Agaw) language spoken by about 90 000 speakers in central Eritrea and eastern Sudan.
Dahalo is an endangered Cushitic language spoken by ca. 400 speakers on the northern coast of Kenya. It is represented here in IPA according to Maddieson et al. (1993).

(Standard) German is a Germanic language used by about 90 million native speakers mainly in Germany, Austria and Switzerland. It is represented here in the standard orthography. Grammatical abbreviations: f 'feminine', m 'masculine', n 'neuter' (gender).

Dogul Dom (or Dogulu) is a Western Dogon language spoken over a wide but sparsely-populated area on the high, flat plateau that begins a few kilometers north of Bandiagara and south of the Tommo So zone.

Daasanach (Dhaasanac and similar) is a Lowland East Cushitic language spoken by about 60 000 speakers in southern Ethiopia and northern Kenya.It is represented here in a linguistic transcription (IPA).
English is a Germanic language spoken by about 360 million native speakers mainly in the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada, Australia, Ireland and New Zealand.
Ewondo is a Bantu language (A72).
Fang is Bantu language (A75) spoken by about 1 million speakers in Gabon, Equatorial Guinea and southern Cameroon.
(Standard) French (Français) is a Romance (Italic) language spoken by about 75 million native speakers mainly in France, Belgium, Switzerland and Canada. It is an official language in 29 countries.

ǂUngkue (similar: Vaal-Orange, Seroa) was a Tuu variety or language cluster in South Africa (and Lesotho; depending on its definition) and became extinct during the 20th century. It is represented here in a linguistic transcription (IPA).
Gamo belongs to the Gamo-Gofa-Dawro dialect cluster, i.e., an Omotic language spoken by about 2 million speakers in southwestern Ethiopia.
Gourou (ethnic and language name) is an Eastern Dogon language, belonging to the Jamsay dialect and is spoken in several villages mostly south of Koro.
Gusii (Kisii, EkeGusii) is a Bantu language (JE42) spoken by more than 2 million speakers in western Kenya.
Gawwada is an Eastern Cushitic dialect cluster (Yaaku-Dullay branch) and spoken by about 70 000 speakers in  southern Ethiopia.

Gǀui is a Khoe-Kwadi language spoken by about 1500 native speakers mainly in Botswana and belongs to the Gǁana language cluster. It is represented here in the orthography as proposed by Hirosi Nakagawa.
Haya (Oluhaya) is a Bantu language (JE22) spoken by more than 1 million speakers in northwestern Tanzania.
Herero (Otjiherero) is a Bantu language spoken by about 250 000 native speakers mainly in Namibia and Botswana. It is represented here in the standard orthography.

Tshwa (Kua-Tsua, Hietshwa(re)) is a Khoe-Kwadi  language spoken by about 2000 native speakers mainly in Botswana and Zimbabwe. It is represented here in a preliminary linguistic transcription (Fehn)[fehnnotes].
Tshwa (Kua-Tsua, Hietshwa(re)) is a Khoe-Kwadi  language spoken by about 2000 native speakers mainly in Botswana and Zimbabwe. Tshwa/Hietshware is represented here according to Dornan (1917).

ǂ'Amkoe (ǂHõã, Eastern ǂHõã, ǂHoang) is a Kx'a language spoken by less than 100 native speakers in Botswana. It is represented here in a linguistic transcription (Berthold & Gerlach 2011, Nǃaqriaxe variety)[bertholdgerlach2011].
Ik is a Kuliak language spoken by about 8000 speakers in northeastern Uganda.

Jamsay (from a common greeting) is the largest-population Dogon language. It is the dominant language of villages in the plains between and northeast of the major inselbergs in the northeastern area. Mainstream Jamsay extends from the Douentza area southeast to Bamba and Koro, and northeast to the Mondoro area (from where some villages extend into Burkina Faso). Mainstream Jamsay is quite uniform.
Jamsay Mondoro is a Jamsay dialect spoken in the Mondoro Area
Kamba (Kikamba) is a Bantu language (E55) spoken by about 4 million speakers in south-central Kenya.
Kalanga (Ikalanga) is a Bantu language spoken by about 950 000 native speakers mainly in Zimbabwe and Botswana.
Kela is a Bantu language (C75) spoken by probably more than 200 000 speakers in the central region of DR Congo.
accent and vowel length are represented by ´and -
Kimbundu is a Bantu language (H21) spoken by about 4 million native speakers mainly in north-western Angola. It is represented here in the standard orthograhpy.

ǃXun (Northwestern ǃXun, ǃKhung, ǃKung) is a Kx'a  language belonging to the Ju language cluster spoken by several thousand native speakers mainly in Namibia and Angola. It is written here as presented in König & Heine (2008). Grammatical abbreviations: n1 'noun class 1' (hȁ), n3 'noun class 3' (yīí), n4 'noun class 4' (kā), partially grouped as singular/plural, e.g. n1/3 'singular: noun class 1/plural: noun class 3' (cf. König & Heine 2008: 7)[konigheine2008].
Kongo (Kikongo) is a Bantu language (H16).

Juǀ'hoan (Juǀ'hoansi, Southeastern Ju) is a Kx'a  language belonging to the Ju language cluster spoken by about 30 000 native speakers mainly in Namibia and Botswana. It is represented here in the standard orthography (cf. Dickens 1994)[dickens1994]. Grammatical abbreviations: ha/sì 'gender 1' (singular ha, plural sìǃá or sì; human nouns),  ha/hi 'gender 2' (singular ha, plural hì), ha 'gender 3' (singular ha/plural ha), hi 'gender 4' (singular hì/plural hì), ka 'gender 5' (singular ká/plural ká) (cf. Dickens, 2005, A Concise Grammar of Juǀ'hoan: 31ff.).

Wambo (Oshiwambo, Ovambo, including Kwanyama and Ndonga) is a Bantu  language (cluster) spoken by about 1.5 million native speakers mainly in Angola and Namibia. It is represented here in the standard orthography.
Kuvale is a Bantu language (R101) spoken next to the Umbundu-speaking area in Angola. It is represented here in a linguistic transcription (IPA).
Kwadi was a language of southwest Angola related to Khoe languages and became extinct during the 20th century. It is represented here in a linguistic transcription (IPA).
Lango (Lwo, Leb-Lango) is a Western Nilotic language (Southern Luo branch) and spoken by about 1.5 million speakers in northern Uganda.
Lega is a Bantu dialect cluster (D25) with two major varieties, Lega-Shabunda and Lega-Mwenga, spoken in the eastern part of DR Congo by about 500 000 speakers.
Lingala is a Bantu language (C30B).
Luo (Dholuo) is a Western Nilotic languages spoken by about 6 million speakers in western Kenya.

Lower Nossob, including ǀ'Auni (ǀAuni) and ǀHaasi (Kiǀhazi), was a language cluster belonging to the Tuu family spoken in current South Africa, Namibia and Botswana, i.e., in the area of the Kgalagadi Transfrontier National Park. It became extinct during the 20th century. It is represented in a linguistic transcription based on Story & Traill (1999) [traillstory1999] and Dorothea Bleek.

Lower Nossob, including ǀ'Auni (ǀAuni) and ǀHaasi (Kiǀhazi), was a language cluster belonging to the Tuu family and spoken in current South Africa, Namibia and Botswana, i.e., in the area of the Kgalagadi Transfrontier National Park. It became extinct during the 20th century. It is represented in a linguistic transcription based on Story & Traill (1999) and Dorothea Bleek.

Maasai (Masai) is an Eastern Nilotic language spoken by about 1.3 million speakers in Kenya and Tanzania.The forms are taken from Vossen (1988) in a linguistic transcription (IPA). Where Vossen lists several phonological variants, the variant of northwestern dialects (Siria, Purko) was chosen.
Makaa is a Bantu language (A83) spoken by about 100 000 speakers in central Cameroon.
Mangbetu is a Mangbetu-Asua spoken by probably more than 700 000 speakers in the northeast of DR Congo.
Meru (Mero, Kimîîru) is a Bantu language (E53) spoken by about 2 million speakers in central Kenya.
Mba is a Mbaic language spoken by about 40 000 speakers in the central-northern part of DR Congo.
Moru (Kala Moru) is a Moru-Madi language spoken by about 70 000 speakers in South Sudan.

Mombo (exonym Kolu So) is a Western Dogon language, belonging to the Mombo-Ampari group and is spoken in several villages including Songho that are on or near the highway from Mopti-Sevare to Bandiagara. The Nyambeenge and Ambaleenge varieties reported on Blench's website as potentially distinct languages may turn out to be dialects of Mombo from a linguist's perspective, though not necessarily from that of the local people. Most of our data are from Songho village; other dialects like that of Ficko are said to be quite different.
Myene is a cluster of closely related Bantu varieties (B11) spoken by about 50 000 speakers in western Gabon.

Najamba-Kindige (exonym Bondu So) is a Western Dogon language and is thought to be a single language with much dialectal diversity, but Kindige has not yet been studied in depth. Najamba is the local name for the language in several villages in a large canyon beginning just east of Douentza and ending at the huge central Dogon plateau (e.g. Kubewel, Adia). Kindige is an informal local name for the dialects spoken along the highway running west from Douentza (separated from Najamba by a long inselberg and then by the plateau) and into the high plateau including the Borko area.

Nanga is an Eastern Dogon language, belonging to the Beni-Walo-Nanga subgroup and is spoken in five primary villages (Anda, Namakoro, Kono, Wakara, and Soroni) in a compact zone about halfway between Douentza and Bandiagara.

(Namibian Standard) Khoekhoe (Khoekhoegowab, Nama-Damara) is a Khoe-Kwadi language standardized basically on Nama and Damara varieties and spoken by about 200 000 native speakers mainly in Namibia. It is represented here in the standard orthography (Haacke & Eiseb 2002) [haackeeiseb2002]. Grammatical gender is overtly expressed (-b 'masculine', -i 'common', -s 'feminine').

ǂAakhoe is a distinct variety related to (Namibian Standard) Khoekhoe (Khoekhoegowab, Nama-Damara), a Khoe-Kwadi language spoken by about 200 000 native speakers mainly in Namibia. It is represented here in the standard orthography (Haacke & Eiseb 2002) [haackeeiseb2002].

(Namibian Standard) Khoekhoe (Khoekhoegowab, Nama-Damara) is a Khoe-Kwadi language standardized basically on Nama and Damara varieties and spoken by about 200 000 native speakers mainly in Namibia. It is represented here in the standard orthography (Haacke & Eiseb 2002) [haackeeiseb2002]. Grammatical gender is overtly expressed (-b 'masculine', -i 'common', -s 'feminine').

Haiǁom is a distinct variety related to (Namibian Standard) Khoekhoe (Khoekhoegowab, Nama-Damara), a Khoe-Kwadi language spoken by about 200 000 native speakers mainly in Namibia. It is represented here in the standard orthography (Haacke & Eiseb 2002) [haackeeiseb2002].

(Namibian Standard) Khoekhoe (Khoekhoegowab, Nama-Damara) is a Khoe-Kwadi language standardized basically on Nama and Damara varieties and spoken by about 200 000 native speakers mainly in Namibia. It is represented here in the standard orthography (Haacke & Eiseb 2002) [haackeeiseb2002]. Grammatical gender is overtly expressed (-b 'masculine', -i 'common', -s 'feminine').
Nǁang (Nǁng, Nǀuu, Nǀuuki, ǂKhomani) is a Tuu language spoken by probably less than 10 native speakers in South Africa. It is represented here in a linguistic transcription.
Nǁang (Nǁng, Nǀuu, Nǀuuki, ǂKhomani) is a Tuu language spoken by probably less than 10 native speakers in South Africa. It is represented here in a linguistic transcription.
Naro (Nharo) is a Khoe-Kwadi  language spoken by about 10 000 native speakers in Botswana and Namibia. It is represented here in the orthography as used in Visser (2001) [visser2001].
Ngiti is a Lendu(ic) language spoken by about 100 000 speakers in the northeastern part of DR Congo.

Taa (ǃXoon, ǃXóõ) is a Tuu  language spoken by about 3000 native speakers mainly in Botswana and Namibia. It is represented here in the practical orthography proposed by Güldemann & Naumann (2011) [guldemannnaumann2011], except for East !Xoon represented according to Traill 1994 [traill1994]. Grammatical abbreviations: 1 'agreement class 1' (concordial vowel i, tone class ii), 2 'agreement class 2' (concordial vowel ã~a, tone classes i or ii), 3 'agreement class 3' (concordial vowel e, tone classes i or ii), 4 'agreement class 4' (concordial vowel u, tone class ii), 5 'agreement class 5' (concordial sonorant n~ŋ, tone class ii). The classes are paired singular/plural.

Taa (ǃXoon, ǃXóõ) is a Tuu  language spoken by about 3000 native speakers mainly in Botswana and Namibia. It is represented here in the practical orthography proposed by Güldemann & Naumann (2011) [guldemannnaumann2011], except for East !Xoon represented according to Traill 1994 [traill1994]. Grammatical abbreviations: 1 'agreement class 1' (concordial vowel i, tone class ii), 2 'agreement class 2' (concordial vowel ã~a, tone classes i or ii), 3 'agreement class 3' (concordial vowel e, tone classes i or ii), 4 'agreement class 4' (concordial vowel u, tone class ii), 5 'agreement class 5' (concordial sonorant n~ŋ, tone class ii). The classes are paired singular/plural.

Taa (ǃXoon, ǃXóõ) is a Tuu  language spoken by about 3000 native speakers mainly in Botswana and Namibia. It is represented here in the practical orthography proposed by Güldemann & Naumann (2011) [guldemannnaumann2011], except for East !Xoon represented according to Traill 1994 [traill1994]. Grammatical abbreviations: 1 'agreement class 1' (concordial vowel i, tone class ii), 2 'agreement class 2' (concordial vowel ã~a, tone classes i or ii), 3 'agreement class 3' (concordial vowel e, tone classes i or ii), 4 'agreement class 4' (concordial vowel u, tone class ii), 5 'agreement class 5' (concordial sonorant n~ŋ, tone class ii). The classes are paired singular/plural.

Taa (ǃXoon, ǃXóõ) is a Tuu  language spoken by about 3000 native speakers mainly in Botswana and Namibia. It is represented here in the practical orthography proposed by Güldemann & Naumann (2011) [guldemannnaumann2011], except for East !Xoon represented according to Traill 1994 [traill1994]. Grammatical abbreviations: 1 'agreement class 1' (concordial vowel i, tone class ii), 2 'agreement class 2' (concordial vowel ã~a, tone classes i or ii), 3 'agreement class 3' (concordial vowel e, tone classes i or ii), 4 'agreement class 4' (concordial vowel u, tone class ii), 5 'agreement class 5' (concordial sonorant n~ŋ, tone class ii). The classes are paired singular/plural.

Taa (ǃXoon, ǃXóõ) is a Tuu  language spoken by about 3000 native speakers mainly in Botswana and Namibia. It is represented here in the practical orthography proposed by Güldemann & Naumann (2011) [guldemannnaumann2011], except for East !Xoon represented according to Traill 1994 [traill1994]. Grammatical abbreviations: 1 'agreement class 1' (concordial vowel i, tone class ii), 2 'agreement class 2' (concordial vowel ã~a, tone classes i or ii), 3 'agreement class 3' (concordial vowel e, tone classes i or ii), 4 'agreement class 4' (concordial vowel u, tone class ii), 5 'agreement class 5' (concordial sonorant n~ŋ, tone class ii). The classes are paired singular/plural.
Northern Sotho (Sesotho sa Leboa, Sepedi) is a Bantu  language spoken by about 4 million native speakers mainly in South Africa. It is represented here in the standard orthography.
Giryama belongs to the (North) Mijikenda dialect cluster (Bantu E72). Mijikenda is spoken by about 2 million speakers in coastal Kenya and northeastern Tanzania.
Nyankore (Nkore, Runyankore, Nyankole) is a Bantu language (JE13) spoken by about 2.3 million speakers in southwestern Uganda.
Nyakyusa-Ngonde (Nyakyusa) is a Bantu language (M31) spoken by more than 1 million speakers in southwestern Tanzania and northern Malawi.

Penange is a Western Dogon language belonging to the Mombo-Ampari group and is closely related to Ampari. It is spoken in the rather isolated village of Pinia, which is located on a rocky hill with a deep rock pond.

Perge Tegu ('Pergue language') is an Eastern Dogon langauge, belonging to the Jamsay dialect and is spoken in Pergue village, which is on a rocky shelf near Beni. Pergue also has a dye-ers' quarter where mainstream Jamsay is spoken. There are a few other similar montane villages nearby that are said to have distinctive Jamsay dialects.
Portuguese (Português) is a Romance (Italic) language spoken by about 220 million native speakers mainly in Portugal and Brazil. It is an official language in 9 countries.
The reconstructed forms of Proto-Agaw (Proto-Central Cushitic) are taken from Appleyard (2006). It is represented in a linguistic transcription (IPA).
The reconstructed forms of Proto-Highland East Cushitic are taken from Hudson (1989).
Proto-Khoe and a few daughter proto-languages have been reconstructed by Voßen (1997). Proto-Kalahari Khoe (Proto-Non-Khoekhoe, PNK) is represented here in a linguistic transcription (IPA).
The reconstructed forms of Proto-Semitic are taken from Kogan (2011).
The reconstructed forms of Proto-South Cushitic are taken from Ehret (1980).
The reconstructed forms of Proto-West Rift South(ern) Cushitic are taken from Kießling & Mous (2003) in a linguistic transcription (IPA).
Punu is a Bantu language (B43) spoken by about 160 000 speakers in southern Gabon and the Republic of Congo.
Rundi (Kirundi) is a Bantu language (JD62) spoken by about 9 million speakers mainly in Burundi, where it is recognized as official language.
Shua is a Khoe-Kwadi  language spoken by about 2000 native speakers mainly in Botswana. It is represented here in a linguistic transcription (Fehn)[fehnnotes].
Shua is a Khoe-Kwadi  language spoken by about 2000 native speakers mainly in Botswana. It is represented here in a linguistic transcription (Fehn)[fehnnotes].
Sidamo is a Highland East Cushitic language spoken by about 3 million speakers in central Ethiopia.
Shona (chiShona) is a Bantu  language spoken by about 10 million native speakers mainly in Zimbabwe and Mozambique. It is represented here in the standard orthography.
Somali is an Lowland Eastern Cushitic language and spoken by about 15 million speakers mainly in Somalia, Ethiopia and Kenya.
Southern Sotho (Sesotho, Sotho) is a Bantu  language spoken by about 6 million native speakers mainly in South Africa and Lesotho. It is represented here in the standard orthography.

(Standard) Spanish (Castilian, Español, Castellano) is a Romance (Italic) language spoken by about 410 million native speakers mainly in Spain and Hispanic America.It is an official language in 20 countries.

Tebul Ure is a Western Dogon language spoken in another village cluster nearly contiguous to that for Yanda Dom, but mostly on the edge of the high plateau. Yanda Dom and Tebul Ure are geographically separated from other western Dogon languages.

Tiranige Diga (or just Tiranige, exonym Duleri) is a Western Dogon language spoken in a fairly wide area including villages on the northwestern edge of the high plateau and in the plains just below (e.g. Boui). Its genetic position vis-a-vis the Mombo-Ampari group is not yet understood.
Togo Kan is an Eastern Dogon language, belonging to the Tengou-Togo group and is spoken in several villages in the southeastern plains.
dictionary includes information from 5 dialects: plateau, ila, valley, we, mukuni.
Tommo So (variant Tombo So) is an Eastern Dogon language, belonging to the Tommo-Donno subgroup and is spoken in a large area in the plateau; said to have four main dialects; large population.

Tomo Kan is a large-population (second only to Jamsay) Eastern Dogon language spoken in an extensive area in the southern extension of the Bandiagara plateau (e.g. Diangassagou), on the southern cliffs (e.g. Segue), and in the sandy plains east of the cliffs (e.g. Diallassagou).
Tomo Kan is an Eastern Dogon language spoken in in the Diangassagou village, in the southern extension of the Bandiagara plateau

Toro Tegu ('mountain language') is an Eastern Dogon language spoken in villages ringing (and formerly on the summits of) Tabi and Sarinyere mountains, southeast and southwest of the large town of Boni. Toro Tegu is unusual in not being strictly verb-final.
Tswana (Setswana) is a Bantu  language spoken by about 6 million native speakers mainly in South Africa and Botswana. It is represented here in the standard orthography.
Ts'ixa is a Khoe-Kwadi  language spoken by probably less than 1000 native speakers in Botswana. It is represented here  in a linguistic transcription (Fehn)[fehnnotes].
ǀXam was a language cluster belonging to the Tuu family in current South Africa and became extinct in the early 20th century. It is represented here in a linguistic transcription.
Xhosa (isiXhosa) is a Bantu language spoken by about 8 million native speakers mainly in South Africa. It is represented here in the standard orthography.

Kgalagadi (Shekgalagadi, Kalahari, Qhalaxarzi) is a Bantu  language spoken by about 40 000 native speakers mainly in Botswana. It is represented here in a linguistic transcription (Dickens 1986) [dickens1986].
Khwe (Khwedam, Kxoe) is a Khoe-Kwadi  language spoken by about 8000 native speakers mainly in Namibia, Botswana and Angola. It is represented here as given in Kilian-Hatz (2003) [kilianhatz2003].
Khwe (Khwedam, Kxoe) is a Khoe-Kwadi  language spoken by about 8000 native speakers mainly in Namibia, Botswana and Angola. It is represented here as given in Kilian-Hatz (2003) [kilianhatz2003].
Khwe (Khwedam, Kxoe) is a Khoe-Kwadi  language spoken by about 8000 native speakers mainly in Namibia, Botswana and Angola. It is represented here as given in Kilian-Hatz (2003) [kilianhatz2003].

Yanda Dom ('Yanda language') is a Western Dogon language spoken in the Yanda village cluster and in a few additional villages at the base of the cliffs south of Jamsay-speaking Bamba. Former village sites on the high plateau above have been abandoned. The village of Ana has a distinctive dialect.
Yorno So (Yendouma village) is an Eastern Dogon language, belonging to the Toro So varieties.
Zande is a Zandic language spoken by more than 1 million speakers in eastern Central African Republic and in northeastern parts of DR Congo.
Zulu (isiZulu) is a Bantu  language (S42) spoken by about 10 million native speakers mainly in South Africa. It is represented here in the standard orthography.

Krongo (Korongo, Kurungu) is a Kadu language spoken in Kordofan by  21,700 native speakers (1984). In the orthography used by Reh 1985, b d signify implosives, ʈ a dental retroflex, long vowels and consonsant are doubled, cf. p. 9, 10f., 28.

Tumtum is a threatened Kadu language spoken in Kordofan. In the orthography used by Seligmann 1910, x̄ and x̆ mark long and short vowels respectively, x́ indicates word stress. For these and the transcription of consonants cf. p. 170f.
Kanga is a threatened Kadu language spoken in Kordofan by a population of 8,000 (1989). For a description of the phonology cf. Dafalla 2006: 157f.

Katcha-Kadugli-Miri (Kadugi, Central Kadu) is a threatened dialect cluster spoken in Kordofan. In the orthography used by Matsushita 1984-1986, E and O = mid-low vowels ɛ and ɔ, B = bilabial implosive, t d = dental stops, d’ = alveolar implosive, T D = alveolar stops, ‘ = glottal stop, j = palatal affricate, ny = palatal nasal, y palatal glide, tones are marked x́ = high, x = mid, x̀ = low, cf. pp. 15f.
Tulishi (Kuntulishi, Thulishi, Tulesh) is a threatened Kadu language spoken in Kordofan by a population of 2,700 (2007). It is represented here as in Dafalla 2006.
Keiga (Yega) is a Kadu language spoken in Kordofan. It is represented in the orthography used in Blench 2005.
Nyangˈi (Nyangia) is a nearly extinct Kuliak language spoken in northeastern Uganda by 20 speakers (2011) after a language shift to Karamojong. It is represented here as in Heine 1975.
Soo (So, Tepeth) is a moribund Kuliak language spoken in northeastern Uganda by 50 speakers (2012) after a language shift to Karamojong. It is represented here as in Heine 1975.
Lendu (Balendru) is a Central Sudanic language spoken by 750,000 speakers in the northeastern Democratic Republic of the Congo and by 10,000 speakers in Uganda (1996).
Lombi is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the northeastern Democratic Republic of the Congo.
Asoa (Asua, Asuae, Asuati, Aka) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the Democratic Republic of the Congo by 26,000 speakers (2000).
Bendi is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the northeastern Democratic Republic of the Congo by 32,000 speakers (1991).
Efe (= Lese, Lissi according to Bahuchet 2006) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the northeastern Democratic Republic of the Congo by 70,000 speakers (1991).
Lese (Lissi, = Efe according to Bahuchet 2006) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the northeastern Democratic Republic of the Congo by 70,000 speakers (1991).
Mvuba is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the northeastern Democrativ Republic of the Congo and Uganda spoken by a total of 6,000 speakers (2000).
Mamvu is a Central Sudanic language in the northeastern Democratic Republic of the Congo spoken by 60,000 speakers (1991).
Mangbutu is a Central Sudanic language in the northeastern Democratic Republic of the Congo spoken by 15,000 speakers (1991).
Ndo is a Central Sudanic language spoken by 100,000 speakers in the northeastern Democratic republic of the Congo (1991) and 34,000 in western Uganda (2002).
Omi is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the former Orientale Province of the Democratic Republic of the Congo by 91,000 speakers (2005).
Baka (Sudan) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in South Sudan by 26,000 Speakers (1993).
Beli (Sudan) (‘Beli, Jur Beli) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in South Sudan by 65,000 speakers (2009).
Mo‘da (Gberi) is part of the Central Sudanic dialect continuum Morokodo spoken in South Sudan by 50,000 speakers (2011).
Morokodo is a Central Sudanic dialect continuum spoken in South Sudan by 50,000 speakers (2011).
Nyamusa-Molo is part of the Central Sudanic dialect continuum Morokodo spoken in South Sudan by 50,000 speakers (2011).
Fongoro is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the Republic of Chad by few remaining speakers (2007).

Gula (Tar Gula, Kara) is a Central Sudanic dialect continuum spoken in the Central African Republic and South Sudan by 13,000 speakers (1996). It is represented here in various dialect forms taken from Nougayrol 1999.
Kara (Fer, Dam Fer, Fertit) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the northern Central African Republic by 5,000 speakers (1996).
Lutos (Ruto) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the Central African Republic and Chad by 19,000 speakers (1993-1996).
Vale is a minor Central Sudanic language spoken in the Central African Republic by 5,400 speakers (1996).
Disa is a minor Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad by 2,400 speakers (2000).
Kenga is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad by 40,000 speakers (1997).
Gula (Chad) (Sara Gula) is a Central Sudanci language spoken in Chad by 10,300 speakers (2000).
Morom (Bernde) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad by 4,500 speakers (2002).
Berakou (Beraku) is an extinct Central Sudanic language of Chad, whose speakers have shifted to Babalia Creole Arabic
Naba is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad by 280,000 speakers (2006).
Gulay (Gulai, Gulei) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad by 160,000 speakers (1993).
Horo is an extinct Central Sudanic language of Chad. Its speakers have shifted to Ngam.
Sar (Sara, Madjingay, Sara madjingay) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in southern Chad by 180,000 speakers (1993). It is a regional lingua franca.
Kaba (Kabba, Kaba of Goré) is a Central Sudanic language spoken by 72,000 speakers (1996) in the Central African Republic and by 11,000 speakers in Chad.
Laka (Kabba Laka) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chade by 57,000 speakers (1993). It is represented here in the French transcription of Périquet 1915.
Ngambay (Sara, Sara Ngambai, Gamba, Gambaye, Gamblai, and Ngambai) a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad, Cameroon and Nigeria by 950,000 speakers (2005-2006).
Bedjond (Nangnda) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad by 36,000 speakers (1969).
Gor is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad by 87,000 speakers (2006).
Mango is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad by 52,000 speakers (2006).
Dagba is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the Central African Republic and Chad by 44,000 speakers (2007).
Mbay (Sara Mbay) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad and the Central African Republic by 90,000 speakers (1990-1996).
Ngam (Sara Ngam) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad and the Central African Republic by 61,000 speakers (1993-1996).
Furu is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the Democratic Republic of the Congo by 16,000 speakers (1984-1996).
Sara Kaba is a Central Sudanic language.
Sara Kaba Deme (Kaba Démé, Kaba ’Dem, Ta Sara, Dem) is a Central Sudanic Language spoken by 40,000 speakers in Chad (1993) and by an unknown number of speakers in the Central African Republic.
Sara Kaba Náà is a Central Sudanic language.
Kulfa (Kaba So) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad by 7,100 speakers (1993).
Yulu (Binga) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in the Central African Republic, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, South Sudan and Sudan by 13,000 speakers (1987-2011).
Sinyar (Shemya) is a Central Sudanic language spoken in Chad by 12,000 speakers (2000). It is represented here in the French transcription of Grossards 1925.
Humburi Senni Songhay is an Eastern Songhay language spoken in Burkina Faso and Mali by 25,000 speakers (1999-2011).
Koyraboro Senni Songhai is an Eastern Songhay language spoken in Mali by 430,000 native speakers (2007).
Tondi Songway Kiini is an Eastern Songhay language spoken in Mali by 3,000 native speakers (1998).
Dendi (Benin) is an Eastern Songhay language spoken in northern Benin by 32,000 native speakers (1995). It is a regional trade language and heavily influenced by Bariba.
Korandje (Kwaranje) is a Songhay language spoken in the oasis of Tabelbala in Algeria by 3,000 native speakers (2010). It is heavily influenced by Berber and Arabic.
Tadaksahak (Dawsahak) is a Songhay language spoken in Mali by 100,000 native speakers (2007). It is strongly influenced by neighbouring Tuareg languages.
Tagdal (Gadal) is a Songhay language spoken in Niger by 27,000 native speakers. About half of its everyday vocabulary is Tuareg.
Tasawaq (Sawaq, Ingelshi) is a Songhay language spoken in Niger by 8,000 nactive speakers (1998). It is strongly influenced by Tuareg.
Kunama is an isolated language spoken in Eritrea and Ethiopia by 190,000 native speakers (2006-2007).
Shabo (Chabo, Mikeyir) is an endangered, probably isolated language spoken in Ethiopia by 400 native speakers (2000). Lexically, it is heavily influenced by Majang, Shekkacho and Amharic.
Amdang (Biltine, Mimi) is a Furan language spoken by 41,000 native speakers mainly in Chad with small colonies in Sudan. It is represented here as recorded in the village of Yaouada.
Fur (Konjara) is a Fur language spoken in Sudan and Chad by 745,000 native speakers (2004).
Beria (Zaghawa) is an Eastern Saharan language spoken in eastern central Chad and northwestern Sudan by 270,000 native speakers (2006). It is represented here in the Kube dialect
Berti (Sagato-a) is an extinct Eastern Saharan language formerly spoken in Sudan. It is represented here based on varying sources compiled by Petráček 1987.
Bilma Kanuri is part of the Kanuri dialect continuum spoken by a total of 4.2 million native speakers (1985-2006) mainly in Nigeria, Niger, Chad and Cameroon.
Dazaga (Daza) is a Western Saharan language spoken in northern Chad by 380,000 native speakers (2006-2007).
Tedaga (Teda) is a Western Saharan language spoken in Libya, Chad and Niger by 43,000 native speakers (1993-1998).
Nuclear Masalit is a Maban language spoken in western Sudan by 410,000 native speakers (2006-2010).
Maba (Chad) (Madan, Mabang) is a Maban language spoken in Chad and Sudan by 300,000 speakers (2006). It is a local trade language.
Karanga is a Maban language spoken in Chad by 10,000 native speakers (1999).
Kibet (Kibeit, Kibeet, Kabentang) is a Maban language spoken in Chad by 19,000 native speakers (1983).
Runga (Roungo) is a Maban language spoken in Chad and the Central African Republic by 43,000 native speakers (1993-1996).
Mimi-Nachtigal is a language of Chad classified as Maban and attested only in a single wordlist by Gustav Nachtigal c. 1870.
Mararit is a Taman language spoken in eastern Chad by 42,000 native speakers (1993).
Miisiirii is a Taman language spoken in western Sudan.
Assangori is a Taman language spoken in eastern Chad and western Sudan by 24,000 native speakers (1993).

Tama (Chad) (Damut) is a Taman language of eastern Chad and western Sudan. Together with Miisiirii, it is spoken by 68,000 native speakers (1970-1993). It is represented here based on various sources compiled by Edgar 1991.

Afitti (Dinik, Ditti, Unietti) is a Nyimang language spoken in Sudan by 4,000 native speakers (2009). It is represented here based on Stevenson apud Bender 2000 with tones marked as follows: ` = low, ̄	= mid, ´ = high

Ama (Sudan) (Nyimang) is a Nyimang language spoken in Sudan by 70,000 native speakers (1982). It is represented here based on Stevenson apud Bender 2000 with tones marked as follows: ` = low, ̄	= mid, ´ = high
Nara (Nera, Barea, Barya) is a Nilo-Saharan language spoken in Eritrea by 81,000 speakers (2006).
Nobiin (Mahas) is a Nubian language spoken in southern Egypt and northern Sudan by 610,000 native speakers (1996-2006).
Birked (Birgid, Birguid, Birqed, Kajjara, Murgi) is a exstinct Nubian language formerly spoken in western Sudan in the 1970s.

Old Nubian is an ancient language of Egypt and Sudan and ancestral to the Nubian language Nobiin. It is preserved mainly in religious writings in the Greek-derived Old Nubian script, which is represented here in Roman transcription.

Haraza is an extinct Nubian language of Sudan, preserved in a wordlist from 1923. It is represented here in the Roman transcription from Arabic; morde detailed information on putative pronunciation is available from the source.
Andaandi (Dongolawi) is a Nubian language spoken in northern Sudan by 70,000 native speakers (2014).
Kenzi (Kenuzi, Mattokki) is a Nubian language spoken in Egypt by 50,000 native speakers (2014).
Dair is a Nubian language spoken in the Nuba Hills of Sudan.
Kadaru is a Nubian language spoken in the Nuba Hills of Sudan.
Uncunwee (Ghulfan) is a Nubian language spoken in the Nuba Hills of Sudan.
Dilling is a Nubian language spoken in the Nuba Hills of Sudan.
Karko is a Nubian language spoken in the Nuba Hills of Sudan.
Wali (Sudan) is a Nubian language spoken in the Nuba Hills of Sudan.
Midob (Meidob) is a Nubain language spoken in Sudan by 50,000 native speakers (1993).
Logorik (Liguri) is a Daju language spoken in Sudan by 2,000 native speakers (1971).
Shatt (Caning) is a Daju language spoken in Sudan by 30,000 native speakers (2014).
Dar Daju Daju (Daju Mongo, Wadai Daju) is a Daju language spoken in Chad by 34,000 native speakers.
Dar Sila Daju (Sila, Dar Sila, Bokor, Bokorike, Bokoruge, Dadjo, Dadjou, Sula) is a Dajus language spoken in Chad by 70,00 native speakers and Sudan.
Njalgulgule (Nyolge, Nyalgulgule) is a Daju language spoken by 900 native speakers in a single village in South Sudan (1977). It is represented here in the German orthography used by Seetzen 1816.
Baygo (Beigo, Baigo, Bego, Beko, Béogé, Beygo) is an extinct Daju language formerly spoken in Sudan.
Dar Fur Daju (Dar Fur, Nyala) is a Daju language spoken in Sudan by 80,000 native speakers (1983).
Nuclear Temein (Ronge, Roge) is a language spoken in the Nuba Hills of Sudan by 13,000 native speakers (2006).
Tese (Teisei) is a language spoken in the Nuba Hills of Sudan by less than 1,400 native speakers (1971).
Bari (Nilotic) is a Nilotic language spoken in South Sudan and Uganda by 750,000 native speakers (2000-2014).

Kakwa is a Nilotic language spoken in South Sudan, Uganda and the Democratic Republic of the Congo by about 200,000 – 300,000 native speakers (2012). It is also regarded as a dialect of Bari (Nilotic).
Mandari is a Nilotic language spoken in South Sudan by 70,000 native speakers (2014). It is also considered a dialect of Bari (Nilotic).
Dongotono is a Nilotic language spoken in South Sudan by about 5,000 native speakers (2013).
Lokaya (Ellyria, Koyo, Loirya, Lokoiya, Lokoja, Loquia, Lowoi, Oirya, Owoi, Oxoriok) is a Nilotic language spoken in South Sudan by 12,000 native speakers.
Lopit is a Nilotic language spoken in South Sudan by 50,000 native speakers.
Otuho (Lotuko, Lotuxo) is a Nilotic language spoken in South Sudan by 140,000 native speakers (1977).
Ngasa (Ongamo) is a Nilotic language of Tanzania that has probably become extinct (2012) after a language shift to Chagga.

Samburu is an Eastern Nilotic language spoken in Kenya by 240,000 native speakers (2009). The forms given here are taken from Vossen 1988, where different forms for the Samburu and Camus dialects are sometimes given. Of these, the former are preferred.
Teso (Ateso) is an Esatern Nilotic language spoken in Kenya and Uganda by 1.9 million speakers (2002, 2009).
Karamojong (Ngakarimojong, N‘Karamojong) is an Eastern Nilotic language spoken in Uganda by 740,000 native speakers (2002).

Nyangatom (Inyangatom, Donyiro, Dongiro, Idongiro) is an Eastern Nilotic language spoken in Ethiopia by 24,000 native speakers (2007). Examples are taken from Schröder-Kadanya 2011, where an underscore indicates a voiceless vowel.
Turkana is an Eastern Nilotic language spoken in Kenya by 990,000 native speakers (2009).

Kipsigis (Kipsikii, Kipsikiis) is a Southern Nilotic language that is part of the Kalenjin dialect cluster. It is spoken in Kenya by 1.9 million native speakers (2009). Entries in Rottland 1982 may be cited in their primary (unenlarged) or secondary (enlarged) form, depending on which form was most frequently given by the informants (cf. p. 292).

Keiyo (Elgeyo) is a Southern Nilotic language that is part of Kalenjin dialect cluster. It is spoken in Kenya by 314,000 native speakers (2009). Entries in Rottland 1982 may be cited in their primary (unenlarged) or secondary (enlarged) form, depending on which form was most frequently given by the informants (cf. p. 292).

Nandi (Naandi) is a Southern Nilotic language that is part of the Kalenjin dialect cluster. It is spoken in Kenya by 950,000 native speakers (2009). In the conventional orthography, ng‘ ny and ch stand for ŋ (velar nasal) ɲ (palatal nasal) and c (palatal stop) respectively. Creider-Creider 2001 additionally use ö to signify the [+ATR] vowel /a/, which is normally spelled <a>. The IPA transcription is adapted from Creider-Creider 2001. Tones are marked x́ = high tone, x̂ = high-falling tone, x̀ = low-falling tone, x = falling tone (cf. p. 15).

Terik is a Southern Nilotic language that is part of Kalenjin dialect cluster. It is spoken in Kenya by 300,000 native speakers (2009). Entries in Rottland 1982 may be cited in their primary (unenlarged) or secondary (enlarged) form, depending on which form was most frequently given by the informants (cf. p. 292).

Tugen is a Southern Nilotic language that is part of the Kalenjin dialect cluster. It is spoken in Kenya by 140,000 native speakers (2009). Entries in Rottland 1982 may be cited in their primary (unenlarged) or secondary (enlarged) form, depending on which form was most frequently given by the informants (cf. p. 292).

Kupsabiny (Sabiny, Sebei) is a Southern Nilotic language that is part of the Kalenjin dialect cluster. It is spoken in Uganda by 181,000 native speakers (2002). Entries in Rottland 1982 may be cited in their primary (unenlarged) or secondary (enlarged) form, depending on which form was most frequently given by the informants (cf. p. 292).

Sabaot is a Southern Nilotic language that is part of the Kalenjin dialect cluster. It is spoken around Mt. Elgon in Uganda and Kenya by 240,000 native speakers (2002). Entries in Rottland 1982 may be cited in their primary (unenlarged) or secondary (enlarged) form, depending on which form was most frequently given by the informants (cf. p. 292).

Markweeta (Markweta) is a Southern Nilotic language that is part of the Kalenjin dialect cluster. Its northern are southern dialect are called Endo and Sambirir respectively. It is spoken in Kenya by 180,000 native speakers (2009). Entries in Rottland 1982 may be cited in their primary (unenlarged) or secondary (enlarged) form, depending on which form was most frequently given by the informants (cf. p. 292).

Pökoot (Pokot, Päkot, Pökot, Suk) is a Southern Nilotic language that is part of the Kalenjin dialect cluster. It is spoken in Kenya and Uganda by 700,000 native speakers (2002-2009). In the orthography used by Beech 1911, long and short voewels are marked v̄ v̌ respectively, ô stands for a (long?) low-back [ɒ], ñg for [ŋ], ng for [ŋg], gh for [ɣ] and ء for a final glottal stop [ʔ].

Mosiro (Akie) is an extinct Southern Nilotic language that was part of the Kalenjin dialect cluster. It was spoken in Tanzania by the Mosiro, Mediak and Kisankasa. Entries in Rottland 1982 may be cited in their primary (unenlarged) or secondary (enlarged) form, depending on which form was most frequently given by the informants (cf. p. 292).
Okiek (Ogiek, Akiek) is a Southern Nilotic language that is part of the Kalenjin dialect cluster. It is spoken by 79,000 hunter-gatherers in Kenya (2009) and some older speakers in Tanzania.

Datooga (Datog, Datoga, Tatoga, Tatog, Taturu, Mang‘ati) is a Southern Nilotic dialect cluster sopken in Tanzania by 88,000 native speakers (2000). In Rottland 1982, dialects are number coded as follows: Bajuta 1, Gisamjanga 2a, Barabaiga 2b, Isimijega 3, Rotigenga 4, Buradiga 5, Bianjida 6.
Omotik (Sawas) is a moribund Southern Nilotic Language spoken by 50 older adults (1980) of the hunter-gatherer Omotik people in Kenya.
